author: Rob Crilly
title: Admiral among US Navy officers accused of trading sex for secrets
text:
News Admiral among US Navy officers accused of trading sex for secrets Francis laid on sex parties for officers of the USS Blue Ridge, pictured, according to the newly unsealed indictment Credit: Getty Images Rob Crilly , New York 15 March 2017 • 12:42am 
T he fraudster at centre of scandal known as ‘Fat Leonard’ has admitted using prostitutes and extravagant dinners to coax vessels in the US Seventh Fleet to his contracting facilities. 
The American Navy officers are accused of accepting Cuban cigars, tens of thousands of dollars of Champagne and the services of prostitutes . 
In return, they allegedly supplied inside information on the movements of US Seventh Fleet to a man known as Fat Leonard who used the tips to secure inflated contracts for his maritime servicing company. 
On Tuesday, another nine current and former officers were charged in one of the biggest corruption scandals to rock the US Navy as newly unsealed court documents revealed fresh details of alleged wrongdoing. 
They include Admiral Bruce Loveless, who was the Navy’s director of intelligence operations until he retired in October, and Captain David Newland, chief of staff to the Commander of the Seventh Fleet. Leonard Glenn Francis who earned his nickname thanks to his 25-stone frame 
T hey are all accused of taking bribes from Leonard Glenn Francis, who earned his nickname thanks to his 25-stone frame. He faces up to 25 years in prison after admitting defrauding the Navy of tens of millions of dollars. 
Francis used his expensive gifts to persuade officers steer naval vessels to ports operated by his company, Glenn Marine Defense Asia, where he overcharged for providing fuel, water and logistics support. 
He laid on sex parties for officers of the USS Blue Ridge, the 7th fleet’s flag ship, according to the newly unsealed indictment, which details the litany of accusations. 
O n one occasion in 2006, he picked up a $20,000 (£16,000) restaurant bill for officers in Hong Kong. Admiral Bruce Loveless Credit: Courtesy The San Diego Union-Tribune/AP 
T he charge sheet lists the menu for another occasion: black truffle soup, rock lobster salad, oscetra caviar, pan-seared duck liver, Dover sole, grilled Wagyu beef. 
And then there was the sex party allegedly themed around one of the most famous generals in US military history. 
In February 2007, Francis provided prostitutes at the MacArthur Suite of the Manila Hotel, in the Philippines – named after the island nation’s Second World War liberator. 
“During the party, historical memorabilia related to General Douglas MacArthur were used by the participants in sexual acts,” reads the indictment. 
Prosecutors say Francis cheated the Navy out of $35 million in all. 
The defendants were arrested on Tuesday in California, Texas, Pennsylvania, Florida, Colorado and Virginia. 
“This is a fleecing and betrayal of the United States Navy in epic proportions, and it was allegedly carried out by the Navy's highest-ranking officers,” said Alana Robinson, acting US attorney, adding that the officers stand accused of trading secrets for sex. 
The documents allege officers used private email accounts to keep their activities from their superiors and referred to themselves variously as the Brotherhood, the Wolfpack, the familia, and the Lion King's Harem. 
For those who knew about Fat Leonard’s lucrative sideline he was also known as the Lion King. 
He was arrested in 2013 after being lured to a hotel in San Diego, a major hub used by the US Pacific Fleet. 
S ince then 20 naval officers have been charged along with staff of his Singapore-based company . 
Until now one of the most senior officers was Captain Daniel Dusek, the former commander of the USS Bonhomme Richard, an amphibious assault vessel. He was sentenced to 46 months in prison last year after admitting his role in the scandal. 
In all, 13 have pleaded guilty while several other cases are pending. Follow Telegraph News
